misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a program to compute average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time instead of a program that reads 5 integers and outputs the sum of the even numbers. This indicates they did not understand or follow the actual problem specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: I need to write a program that reads v0, v1, and t, computes average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t, and prints that result.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check which of them are even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print the sum in the specified format.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
No loop to process 5 inputs
No conditional check for even numbers
Output describes 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely confused this question with a different textbook-style problem about physics/acceleration or did not carefully read the current assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Then design the program to (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop over the 5 inputs, (3) use an if-statement with n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers, (4) add even numbers to a running sum, and (5) print the sum in the required format.
related_concepts: Mapping requirements to code structure (input, loop, condition, accumulator)
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the code (inputs, variable names, formula, and printed message) corresponds to an average-acceleration problem, and none of it matches the required task of summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: This code solves an average-acceleration problem (3 double inputs, physics formula, and acceleration output) instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones, showing a clear mismatch with the question requirements.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration, requiring 3 double inputs and a formula) instead of the required task (calculating the sum of even numbers from 5 integer inputs, requiring iteration and conditional logic). None of the assignment's core requirements (reading 5 integers, using a loop, checking for even numbers, accumulating a sum) were met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task was to calculate average acceleration given initial velocity, final velocity, and time.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required a program to read 5 integers, use a loop to process them, apply a conditional check to identify even numbers (using modulo 2), and calculate an accumulated sum of only those even numbers.
symptoms: Program prompts for and reads 'v0, v1, and t:'
Uses double data types instead of integers.
Program performs a physics calculation instead of iteration and summation logic.
Missing loop and conditional structure.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to read and adhere to the prompt instructions for Q1: Sum of Even Numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please carefully re-read the required program description ('Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers') and implement that specific functionality.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The supplied code is a complete solution for a known formula problem (average acceleration) and shows no attempt to address the 'Sum of Even Numbers' prompt.

evidence.note: The entire program implements the functionality for calculating average acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misunderstanding of Problem Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student has solved a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration, reading three floating-point values (v0, v1, and t) and computing average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user and computing the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Program reads 3 doubles instead of 5 integers
Program performs division calculation instead of checking for even numbers
Program outputs acceleration instead of sum of even numbers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to filter even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Fundamental misunderstanding of the problem specification. The student either read the wrong problem statement or conflated this assignment with a different physics-related problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem carefully: the task is to read 5 integers and sum only the even ones. Use a loop (for or while) to read 5 integers, check if each is even using modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), and accumulate the sum of even numbers only.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code solves a completely different problem (physics acceleration) with no connection to the assigned problem (sum of even numbers). This is not a partial solution or edge case—it is fundamentally solving the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Student reads 3 floating-point values (velocity and time) instead of 5 integers as required by the problem.

evidence.snippet:
double avg_acceleration = (finalVelocity - v0) / t_val;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + avg_acceleration);
evidence.note: Student calculates and outputs acceleration (physics formula), not the sum of even numbers as required.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones, indicating a misunderstanding of the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, check which of them are even, compute the sum of those even numbers, and print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Uses three double variables (v0, finalVelocity, t_val) instead of five integers.
Computes (finalVelocity - v0) / t_val instead of summing selected inputs.
No loop, no modulus operator, and no handling of five distinct numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with a different exercise about average acceleration, leading to reusing that solution instead of implementing the required even-sum logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Before coding, restate the problem in your own words and list the required inputs, outputs, and steps. Double-check that your variable names, prompts, and calculations match the current problem (5 integers and sum of evens), not a different exercise.
related_concepts: Mapping problem statements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt text, variables, formula) matches a standard acceleration example and does not address any element of the stated task.

evidence.note: This code clearly implements an average acceleration calculation rather than reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Misinterpretation of Assignment Requirements
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration instead of the required task: reading 5 integers and calculating the sum of the even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they were asked to write a program to calculate average acceleration, or they submitted the wrong file for the assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment required reading 5 integers, using a loop structure, and applying conditional logic (modulo operator) to sum only the even numbers.
symptoms: The code uses input variables (v0, v1, t) unrelated to the assignment.
The core logic calculates acceleration (formula: (v1 - v0) / t) instead of a sum of even numbers.
The program reads 3 inputs instead of 5.
The variable types used are 'double' instead of 'int'.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to correctly read or adhere to the assigned prompt (Q1. Sum of Even Numbers).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully reread the assignment prompt (Q1) and ensure the submitted code addresses the specified objective: reading 5 integers, using a loop, checking for evenness, and accumulating the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code solves a different, unrelated physics problem (acceleration) entirely, leading to 0 points across all rubric categories.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to calculating acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Problem Requirement Misinterpretation
misconceptions.description: The student appears to have misunderstood or misread the assignment entirely. Instead of writing a program to sum even numbers from 5 integer inputs, they wrote an acceleration calculator that reads 3 decimal values and computes a physics formula.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they should calculate average acceleration from velocity and time inputs, suggesting they are solving a different problem or assignment altogether.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, identifying which ones are even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulating their sum, and printing the result with the format 'Sum of even numbers: XX'.
symptoms: Program reads only 3 values instead of 5
Program reads floating-point values instead of integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of sum of evens
No loop structure present
No conditional check for even numbers
Output format is completely incorrect
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong assignment specification or fundamentally misunderstood what was being asked. This could be due to copy-pasting code from a previous assignment, not reading the problem statement carefully, or confusion about which question they were answering.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh: re-read the Q1 requirement line-by-line. Write pseudocode first: 'prompt user for 5 integers, loop 5 times, check if each number is even, if yes add to sum, print final sum.' Then implement each step.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's code solves a completely different problem (physics/acceleration) with a different algorithm, different input count, different data types, and different output. This is not ambiguous—it is definitively the wrong assignment.

evidence.note: The entire program solves an acceleration calculation problem (physics), not a sum-of-even-numbers problem. Class name is 'AccelerationCalculator', input prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t', calculation is the acceleration formula, and output shows 'The average acceleration'. This is the wrong assignment entirely.
Reads only 3 values, all doubles. Assignment requires reading 5 integers. No loop present to read multiple values iteratively.
Implements acceleration formula (change in velocity / time), not the required logic: filtering for even numbers and accumulating their sum.
